```{r setup, include=FALSE}
#Set up library 
library(googlesheets4)
library(janitor)

#Pull in Data 
dat <- read_sheet("https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1h1ZudRdrVLPs_HSrMyJs0rd5kMD5vNh6D0ZvEeYN45g/edit#gid=0")

dat <- clean_names(dat)

shortname <- c("years",
"sector_my",
"role_my",
"my_region",
"acc_type",
"sector_mature",
"sector_should",
"role_success",
"role_should",
"gov_path",
"who_should",
"diff_bounties",
"diff_public_bodies",
"diff_open_audit_tool",
"diff_public_procurement",
"diff_impact_assess",
"diff_audit",
"diff_direct_sh",
"diff_antic_interest_sh",
"diff_disp_outcome",
"diff_dataset_acc",
"diff_expl",
"matur_bounties",
"matur_public_bodies",
"matur_open_audit_tool",
"matur_public_procurement",
"matur_impact_assess",
"matur_audit",
"matur_direct_sh",
"matur_antic_interest_sh",
"matur_disp_outcome",
"matur_dataset_acc",
"matur_expl",
"obstacles",
"comment")

#Rename columns with the list of short column names (names are too long otherwise)
colnames(dat) <- c(shortname)

```

## Including Plots

You can also embed plots, for example:

```{r pressure, echo=FALSE}
plot(pressure)
```

Note that the `echo = FALSE` parameter was added to the code chunk to prevent printing of the R code that generated the plot.
